snippet.title: Depp's ex wife to give evidence in UK libel case
snippet.description:
(20 Jul 2020) American model-actress Amber Heard arrived at London's High Court on Monday to begin three days of evidence in the final week's proceedings of ex-husband Johhny Depp's libel suit against a British tabloid that accused him of assaulting his former spouse.
Depp used a different entrance, and was ushered through a crowd by security staff.
After a week and a half of testimony from Depp and several current or former employees of Depp and Heard, Heard is due to give her side of the story as she enters the witness box.
The Sun's defence relies on 14 allegations made by Heard of violence by Depp between 2013 and 2016, in settings including his private island in the Bahamas, a rented house in Australia and a private jet.
Heard claims that Depp first hit her in 2013, and put her through a "three-day hostage situation" in Australia in 2015.
She also says he threw a bottle of champagne at her and pushed her onto the floor during her 30th birthday party in 2016.
Depp is suing News Group Newspapers, publisher of The Sun, and the paper's executive editor, Dan Wootton, over an April 2018 article that called him a "wife-beater."
He strongly denies abusing his ex-wife, Amber Heard.
He claims Heard was the aggressor during their volatile relationship, which he has likened to "a crime scene waiting to happen."

snippet.title: Johnny Depp's legal team arrives for appeal against libel ruling
snippet.description:
Amber Heard 's claim that she gave her ¬£5.5million ($7million) divorce settlement to charity was a 'calculated and manipulative lie', Johnny Depp 's lawyers have told the Court of Appeal. The Hollywood star (left in London last year) is trying to overturn a damning High Court ruling that he assaulted his ex-wife (right last year) and put her in fear for her life, and is asking the Court of Appeal to order a retrial of his libel claim against The Sun. Following a three-week trial in July last year, Mr Justice Nicol ruled that Mr Depp, 57, assaulted Ms Heard, 34, on a dozen occasions and put her in 'fear for her life' three times. The judge found that an April 2018 column calling Mr Depp a 'wife beater' was 'substantially true'.  He said 'a recurring theme in Mr Depp's evidence was that Ms Heard had constructed a hoax and that she had done this as an 'insurance policy', and that Ms Heard was a 'gold-digger'. But he added: 'I do not accept this characterisation of Ms Heard.' Today the actor's legal team (David Sherborne QC inset) was back in court to claim the star 'did not receive a fair trial' and is applying for permission to appeal against the ruling at the Royal Courts of Justice in London on Thursday. Neither Mr Depp nor Ms Heard (her lawyer Sasha Wass QC inset) were in court today.

snippet.description:
(9 Jul 2020) Actor Johnny Depp and his ex-wife, actress Amber Heard arrived at the High Court in London on Thursday for the third day of a three-week trial over his libel case against a British newspaper.
Depp is suing News Group Newspapers, publisher of The Sun, and the paper‚Äôs executive editor, Dan Wootton, over an April 2018 article that said he‚Äôd physically abused ex-wife Amber Heard. 
The newspaper's lawyers plan to use Heard's allegations of abuse by Depp to defend the ‚Äúwife beater‚Äù claim.
The trial opened on Tuesday. 
It is one of the first major cases to be held in person since Britain began to lift its coronavirus lockdown.
Depp, 57, and Heard, 34, met on the set of the 2011 comedy ‚ÄúThe Rum Diary‚Äù and married in Los Angeles in February 2015. They divorced in 2017 and now bitterly accuse one another of abuse.
While Heard isn't on trial, the case is also a showdown between the former spouses, who accuse each other of being controlling, violent and deceitful.
It is set to put the two performers‚Äô complex private lives under a microscope.
Depp is also suing Heard in the United States for 50 million US dollars for allegedly defaming him in a Washington Post article about domestic abuse. 
That case is due to be heard next year.

Title: Johnny Depp Loses Libel Case Against Britain's Sun Newspaper, Is The Ball In Amber's Court Now?

Read More Stories Here: www.haveitalldaily.com 

Description:
The case that had a global attention has finally concluded and it is terrible news for millions of Johnny Depp fans as he has lost his highly publicized libel case against the publisher of Britain's The Sun newspaper. The newpaper has earlier claimed that the Pirates Of Caribbean actor was an abusive husband and a wife beater referring to his married life with ex-wife Amber Heard. 
Johnny Depp has sued ‚ÄúThe Sun‚Äôs executive Director‚Äù Dan Wootton and News Group Newspapers over an article accusing the actor of being involved in domestic violence and physical altercation towards Amber Heard when they were together. 
But on Monday, November 2nd, 2020 the UK high court has ruled in favor of the tabloid. But does it mean the court has also confirmed Johnny Depp as a ‚ÄúWife Beater‚Äù? 
As reported by CNN: 
Citing evidence, including photos, audio recordings and Depp's own text messages, lawyers for the newspaper group argued in court filings that Depp "beat his wife Amber Heard, causing her to suffer significant injury, and on occasion leading to her fearing for her life."
Judge Andrew Nicol has passed a historical judgment favoring the News outlet and categorically mentioned the claims made by the News Outlet are substantially true. 
"I have reached these conclusions having examined in detail the 14 incidents on which the defendants rely, as well as the over-arching considerations which the claimant submitted I should take into account," the judge said.
During the trial Depp has admitted having problem with drugs and alcohol but has always denied the accusation of being violent with his partner. 
The case was highly publicized and got heated in the month of July this year and Amber Heard has narrated her side of story acknowledging the tabloid‚Äôs claim to be correct. 
"When Johnny puts his attention on you, with all his intensity and darkness, it is unlike anything I've ever experienced," she said in a written witness statement submitted to the court.
"Some incidents were so severe that I was afraid he was going to kill me, either intentionally or just by losing control and going too far. He explicitly threatened to kill me many times, especially later in our relationship," Heard told the court, according to the UK's PA Media news agency.
The tabloid is one of the subsidiaries owned by Media Magnet Rupert Murdoch released a statement following the verdict: 
"The Sun has stood up and campaigned for the victims of domestic abuse for over 20 years. Domestic abuse victims must never be silenced and we thank the judge for his careful consideration and thank Amber Heard for her courage in giving evidence to the court."  
Now it will be interesting to see if Amber Heard is motivated to pursue it further and take legal action for what has already been substantiated by London High Court, or it‚Äôs the case closed.

Title: Johnny Depp Loses Libel Case Against Britain's Sun Newspaper, Is The Ball In Amber's Court Now?

Read More Stories Here: www.haveitalldaily.com 

Description:
The case that had a global attention has finally concluded and it is terrible news for millions of Johnny Depp fans as he has lost his highly publicized libel case against the publisher of Britain's The Sun newspaper. The newpaper has earlier claimed that the Pirates Of Caribbean actor was an abusive husband and a wife beater referring to his married life with ex-wife Amber Heard. 
Johnny Depp has sued ‚ÄúThe Sun‚Äôs executive Director‚Äù Dan Wootton and News Group Newspapers over an article accusing the actor of being involved in domestic violence and physical altercation towards Amber Heard when they were together. 
But on Monday, November 2nd, 2020 the UK high court has ruled in favor of the tabloid. But does it mean the court has also confirmed Johnny Depp as a ‚ÄúWife Beater‚Äù? 
As reported by CNN: 
Citing evidence, including photos, audio recordings and Depp's own text messages, lawyers for the newspaper group argued in court filings that Depp "beat his wife Amber Heard, causing her to suffer significant injury, and on occasion leading to her fearing for her life."
Judge Andrew Nicol has passed a historical judgment favoring the News outlet and categorically mentioned the claims made by the News Outlet are substantially true. 
"I have reached these conclusions having examined in detail the 14 incidents on which the defendants rely, as well as the over-arching considerations which the claimant submitted I should take into account," the judge said.
During the trial Depp has admitted having problem with drugs and alcohol but has always denied the accusation of being violent with his partner. 
The case was highly publicized and got heated in the month of July this year and Amber Heard has narrated her side of story acknowledging the tabloid‚Äôs claim to be correct. 
"When Johnny puts his attention on you, with all his intensity and darkness, it is unlike anything I've ever experienced," she said in a written witness statement submitted to the court.
"Some incidents were so severe that I was afraid he was going to kill me, either intentionally or just by losing control and going too far. He explicitly threatened to kill me many times, especially later in our relationship," Heard told the court, according to the UK's PA Media news agency.
The tabloid is one of the subsidiaries owned by Media Magnet Rupert Murdoch released a statement following the verdict: 
"The Sun has stood up and campaigned for the victims of domestic abuse for over 20 years. Domestic abuse victims must never be silenced and we thank the judge for his careful consideration and thank Amber Heard for her courage in giving evidence to the court."  
Now it will be interesting to see if Amber Heard is motivated to pursue it further and take legal action for what has already been substantiated by London High Court, or it‚Äôs the case closed. 
What are your thoughts?

snippet.title: Johnny Depp arrives at UK High Court on final day of Amber Heard's testimony
snippet.description:
(23 Jul 2020) JOHNNY DEPP ARRIVES AT UK HIGH COURT ON FINAL DAY OF AMBER HEARD'S TESTIMONY 
Johnny Depp arrived at the High Court in London on Thursday (23 JULY 2020) on what is the final day of Amber Heard's testimony in Depp's libel case against a British tabloid over allegations of domestic violence.
Taking the witness box for a fourth straight day, Heard reiterated allegations of abuse when Depp was on a ‚Äúbender‚Äù that would often last days.
‚ÄúJohnny, when he was clean and sober, could be a wonderful person, generous, loving,‚Äù she said. ‚ÄúHe‚Äôs a remarkable man when he‚Äôs like that and I loved him. The other side of him was a monster but I always held out hope he would get clean and sober.‚Äù
In her first three days of testimony, Heard, 34, has accused Depp of an array of acts of violence, including throwing bottles at her ‚Äúlike grenades,‚Äù headbutting her and even of stubbing out a cigarette on his cheek. She has claimed that she often feared for her life during their tempestuous relationship.
Depp denies abusing Heard and claims she was the aggressor during their tempestuous relationship. 
Depp, 57, is suing The Sun, specifically its publisher, News Group Newspapers, and its executive editor, Dan Wootton, for labeling him in an April 2018 article as a ‚Äúwife-beater.‚Äù 
The Sun‚Äôs defense relies on 14 allegations made by Heard of violence by Depp between 2013 and 2016, in settings as varied as a rented house in Australia, his private island in the Bahamas and a private jet. 
The case is due to finish next week with closing submissions from both sides‚Äô legal teams on Monday and Tuesday.

snippet.title: Depp, Heard arrive for second day of UK libel trial
snippet.description:
(8 Jul 2020) DEPP, HEARD ARRIVE FOR SECOND DAY OF UK LIBEL TRIAL
Actor Johnny Depp and his ex-wife, actress Amber Heard arrived at the High Court in London on Wednesday (8 JULY 2020) for the second day of a three-week trial over his libel case against a British newspaper.
Depp is suing British tabloid The Sun over an April 2018 story headlined ‚ÄúPotty - How can JK Rowling be ‚Äògenuinely happy‚Äô casting wife beater Johnny Depp in the new Fantastic Beasts film?‚Äù 
The newspaper's lawyers plan to use Heard's allegations of abuse by Depp to defend the ‚Äúwife beater‚Äù claim.
The trial over his libel claims opened Tuesday. 
It is one of the first major cases to be held in person since Britain began to lift its coronavirus lockdown.
Depp, 57, and Heard, 34, met on the set of the 2011 comedy ‚ÄúThe Rum Diary‚Äù and married in Los Angeles in February 2015. They divorced in 2017, and now bitterly accuse one another of abuse.
While Heard isn't on trial, the case is also a showdown between the former spouses, who accuse each other of being controlling, violent and deceitful.
 It is set to put the two performers‚Äô complex private lives under a microscope.
Depp is also suing Heard in the United States for 50 million US dollars for allegedly defaming him in a Washington Post article about domestic abuse. 
That case is due to be heard next year.

snippet.title: Depp, Heard arrive at UK court for libel trial
snippet.description:
(16 Jul 2020) Hollywood actor Johnny Depp greeted well-wishers outside Britain's High Court on Thursday, as ex-wife Amber Heard entered through a separate entrance. 
Depp is suing News Group Newspapers, publisher of The Sun, and the paper's executive editor, Dan Wootton, over an April 2018 article that called him a "wife-beater." 
He strongly denies abusing Heard.
Depp and Heard give wildly differing accounts of their volatile relationship, which began after they met on the set of the 2011 comedy ‚ÄúThe Rum Diary.‚Äù 
They married in Los Angeles in February 2015. 
Heard filed for divorce the following year, and the divorce was finalized in 2017.
Depp's ex-partner, actress Vanessa Paradis, is today expected to give evidence via video link.
Heard is due to give evidence in the case later this week.
